what: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
text: Rmarkdown part following article: Esser, L.F., Bailly, D., Lima, M.R., Ré, R. 2024. chooseGCM: toolkit select General Circulation Models R. prep.

title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
text: chooseGCM solution GCMs selection Climate Change research. built Rmarkdown way test properties methods underlying chooseGCM. Results function presented side side changing variables, allowing better comparison. , already downloaded GCMs data. Rmarkdown apply different algorithms implemented chooseGCM increasing area. aim understand point GCM selection starts change. , use Araucaria angustifolia records create buffer increassing size.
code: # Install and open CRAN libraries for(x in c("devtools", "geodata", "terra", "tictoc") ){   if (!require(x, character.only = TRUE)) {       install.packages(x, dependencies = TRUE)       library(x, character.only = TRUE)   } }  # Install and open chooseGCM if (!require("chooseGCM", character.only = TRUE)) {     devtools::install_github("luizesser/chooseGCM")     library("chooseGCM", character.only = TRUE) }  # Install and open caretSDM if (!require("caretSDM", character.only = TRUE)) {     devtools::install_github("luizesser/caretSDM")     library("caretSDM", character.only = TRUE) }

title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
text: obtain GCMs data, recommend using geodata package, links directly WorldClim 2.1 database. previously downloaded GCMs data, example code supplied .
code: gcms <- geodata:::.cmods for (r in c(10)) {   for ( g in gcms ) {     geodata::cmip6_world(model = g,                          ssp = "585",                          time = "2081-2100",                          var = "bioc",                          res = r,                          path = ""     )   } }

title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
text: function import_gcms helps user import data correct way, list GCMs. element list SpatRaster terra package, containing variables. list named GCMs names better plot results.
code: tictoc::tic() s10 <- chooseGCM::import_gcms(path = "~/storage/WC_data/WC_data_all_gcms_10/",                                gcm_names = c("ACCESS-CM2","ACCESS-ESM1-5",                                             "CanESM5-CanOE","CMCC-ESM2",                                             "CNRM-CM6-1-HR","CNRM-CM6-1",                                             "CNRM-ESM2-1","EC-Earth3-Veg",                                             "EC-Earth3-Veg-LR","FIO-ESM-2-0",                                             "GISS-E2-1-G","GISS-E2-1-H",                                             "HadGEM3-GC31-LL","INM-CM5-0",                                             "INM-CM4-8","IPSL-CM6A-LR",                                             "MIROC-ES2L","MIROC6",                                             "MPI-ESM1-2-LR","MPI-ESM1-2-HR",                                             "MRI-ESM2-0","UKESM1-0-LL")) tictoc::toc() ## 0.366 sec elapsed

title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
text: demonstration, use Araucaria angustifolia, brazilian pine, study case. flagship species widely modeled know, key species Atlantic Rainforest biodiversity hotspot. Species records obtained GBIF cleaned excluding records outside native region NAs. set records used build 10 buffers growing size, buffer 1 degree-wide bigger.
code: occ_data <- geodata::sp_occurrence("Araucaria", "angustifolia") ## 1932 records found ## 0-300-600-900-1200-1500-1800-1932 ## 1932 records downloaded occ_data <- occ_data |>   dplyr::filter(lon >= -64) |>    dplyr::filter(lon <= -33) |>    dplyr::filter(lat <= -19.5) |>    dplyr::filter(lat >= -33)  buffer50 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 50000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer100 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 100000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer150 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 150000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer200 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 200000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer250 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 250000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer300 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 300000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer350 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 350000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer400 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 400000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer450 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 450000) |>    sf::st_union() buffer500 <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 500000) |>    sf::st_union() plot(buffer50, axes=T)

title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?
text: First set seed standardize randomic outputs. Now perform Monte Carlo analysis type algorithm different sets variables.
code: set.seed(1)

title: How chooseGCM selection changes with increasing area?

title: Is chooseGCM affected by resolution?
text: Rmarkdown part following article: Esser, L.F., Bailly, D., Lima, M.R., Ré, R. 2024. chooseGCM: toolkit select General Circulation Models R. prep.

title: Is chooseGCM affected by resolution?
text: chooseGCM solution GCMs selection Climate Change research. built Rmarkdown way test properties methods underlying chooseGCM. Results function presented side side changing resolution, allowing better comparison. , already downloaded GCMs data. Rmarkdown apply different algorithms implemented chooseGCM different resolutions. aim understand resolution changes affect GCMs subset selected algorithms. expect results change resolution, since increase resolution just interpolation coarser resolution. 30 arcsec resolution used, considered just local scale due computational time limitations. also restricted variables used bio1 bio12 restrict variation included variables selection (see proper Rmarkdown effects variable selection information).
code: # Install and open CRAN libraries for(x in c("devtools", "geodata", "terra", "tictoc") ){   if (!require(x, character.only = TRUE)) {       install.packages(x, dependencies = TRUE)       library(x, character.only = TRUE)   } }  # Install and open chooseGCM if (!require("chooseGCM", character.only = TRUE)) {     devtools::install_github("luizesser/chooseGCM")     library("chooseGCM", character.only = TRUE) }  # Install and open caretSDM if (!require("caretSDM", character.only = TRUE)) {     devtools::install_github("luizesser/caretSDM")     library("caretSDM", character.only = TRUE) }

title: Is chooseGCM affected by resolution?
text: demonstration, use Araucaria angustifolia, brazilian pine, study case. flagship species key species Atlantic Rainforest biodiversity hotspot. Species records obtained GBIF cleaned excluding records outside native region NAs. set records used build shape accessible area merging buffers 500 km around record.
code: occ_data <- geodata::sp_occurrence("Araucaria", "angustifolia") ## 1932 records found ## 0-300-600-900-1200-1500-1800-1932 ## 1932 records downloaded occ_data <- occ_data |>   dplyr::filter(lon >= -64) |>    dplyr::filter(lon <= -33) |>    dplyr::filter(lat <= -19.5) |>    dplyr::filter(lat >= -33)  study_area <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 500000) |>    sf::st_union()

title: Is chooseGCM affected by resolution?
text: obtain GCMs data, recommend using geodata package, links directly WorldClim 2.1 database. previously downloaded GCMs data, example code supplied .
code: gcms <- geodata:::.cmods for (r in c(10, 5, 2.5)) {   for ( g in gcms ) {     geodata::cmip6_world(model = g,                          ssp = "585",                          time = "2081-2100",                          var = "bioc",                          res = r,                          path = ""     )   } }

what: Is chooseGCM affected by variable selection?
title: Is chooseGCM affected by variable selection?
text: Rmarkdown part following article: Esser, L.F., Bailly, D., Lima, M.R., Ré, R. 2024. chooseGCM: toolkit select General Circulation Models R. prep.

title: Is chooseGCM affected by variable selection?
text: chooseGCM solution GCMs selection Climate Change research. built Rmarkdown way test properties methods underlying chooseGCM. Results function presented side side changing variables, allowing better comparison. , already downloaded GCMs data. Rmarkdown apply different algorithms implemented chooseGCM different variables sets. aim understand different variables sets affect GCMs subset selected algorithms. expect results change varibles sets, since change change core comparison process, values presented. showcase , used four sets bioclimatic variables: (1) Bio1 Bio12, main temperature precipitation variables (Annual Mean Temperature Annual Precipitation, respectively); (2) Temperature variables (Bio1 Bio11); (3) Precipitation variables (Bio12 Bio19); (4) bioclimatic variables.
code: # Install and open CRAN libraries for(x in c("devtools", "geodata", "terra", "tictoc") ){   if (!require(x, character.only = TRUE)) {       install.packages(x, dependencies = TRUE)       library(x, character.only = TRUE)   } }  # Install and open chooseGCM if (!require("chooseGCM", character.only = TRUE)) {     devtools::install_github("luizesser/chooseGCM")     library("chooseGCM", character.only = TRUE) }  # Install and open caretSDM if (!require("caretSDM", character.only = TRUE)) {     devtools::install_github("luizesser/caretSDM")     library("caretSDM", character.only = TRUE) }

title: Is chooseGCM affected by variable selection?
text: demonstration, use Araucaria angustifolia, brazilian pine, study case. flagship species key species Atlantic Rainforest biodiversity hotspot. Species records obtained GBIF cleaned excluding records outside native region NAs. set records used build shape accessible area merging buffers 500 km around record.
code: occ_data <- geodata::sp_occurrence("Araucaria", "angustifolia") ## 1932 records found ## 0-300-600-900-1200-1500-1800-1932 ## 1932 records downloaded occ_data <- occ_data |>   dplyr::filter(lon >= -64) |>    dplyr::filter(lon <= -33) |>    dplyr::filter(lat <= -19.5) |>    dplyr::filter(lat >= -33)  study_area <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_transform(crs=sf::st_crs(6933)) |>   sf::st_buffer(dist = 500000) |>    sf::st_union()

title: Is chooseGCM affected by variable selection?
text: obtain GCMs data, recommend using geodata package, links directly WorldClim 2.1 database. previously downloaded GCMs data, example code supplied .
code: gcms <- geodata:::.cmods for (r in c(10)) {   for ( g in gcms ) {     geodata::cmip6_world(model = g,                          ssp = "585",                          time = "2081-2100",                          var = "bioc",                          res = r,                          path = ""     )   } }

title: Is chooseGCM affected by variable selection?
text: function import_gcms helps user import data correct way, list GCMs. element list SpatRaster terra package, containing variables. list named GCMs names better plot results.
code: tictoc::tic() s10 <- chooseGCM::import_gcms(path = "~/storage/WC_data/WC_data_all_gcms_10/",                                gcm_names = c("ACCESS-CM2","ACCESS-ESM1-5",                                             "CanESM5-CanOE","CMCC-ESM2",                                             "CNRM-CM6-1-HR","CNRM-CM6-1",                                             "CNRM-ESM2-1","EC-Earth3-Veg",                                             "EC-Earth3-Veg-LR","FIO-ESM-2-0",                                             "GISS-E2-1-G","GISS-E2-1-H",                                             "HadGEM3-GC31-LL","INM-CM5-0",                                             "INM-CM4-8","IPSL-CM6A-LR",                                             "MIROC-ES2L","MIROC6",                                             "MPI-ESM1-2-LR","MPI-ESM1-2-HR",                                             "MRI-ESM2-0","UKESM1-0-LL")) tictoc::toc() ## 0.165 sec elapsed

title: The chooseGCM contribution for Species Distribution Modeling
text: predict impact climate change, first downloaded WorldClim 2.1 (Fick & Hijmans, 2017) data current scenario available GCMs, reducing sources variation obtaining raster stacks relative SSP5-8.5/2090 (10 arcmin resolution). SSP especially useful presents extreme scenarios, variation GCMs higher (IPCC, 2022). , imported GCM data R applying function import_gcms, returns list SpatRasters, SpatRaster GCM. structure used input functions chooseGCM package.
code: # Download current data geodata::worldclim_global("bio", 10, path="~/storage/WC_data/current")  # Download GCMs data gcms <- c("ACCESS-CM2", "ACCESS-ESM1-5", "CanESM5-CanOE", "CMCC-ESM2",            "CNRM-CM6-1", "CNRM-CM6-1-HR", "CNRM-ESM2-1", "EC-Earth3-Veg",            "EC-Earth3-Veg-LR", "FIO-ESM-2-0", "GISS-E2-1-G", "GISS-E2-1-H",            "HadGEM3-GC31-LL", "INM-CM4-8", "INM-CM5-0", "IPSL-CM6A-LR",            "MIROC-ES2L", "MIROC6", "MPI-ESM1-2-HR", "MPI-ESM1-2-LR",            "MRI-ESM2-0", "UKESM1-0-LL")  for ( g in gcms ) {   geodata::cmip6_world(model = g,                        ssp = "585",                        time = "2081-2100",                        var = "bioc",                        res = 10,                        path = "~/storage/WC_data/future"   ) } # Import GCMs s <- chooseGCM::import_gcms(path = "~/storage/WC_data/future/climate/wc2.1_10m",                              gcm_names = c("ACCESS-CM2", "ACCESS-ESM1-5", "CanESM5-CanOE",                                           "CMCC-ESM2", "CNRM-CM6-1", "CNRM-CM6-1-HR",                                            "CNRM-ESM2-1", "EC-Earth3-Veg", "EC-Earth3-Veg-LR",                                           "FIO-ESM-2-0", "GISS-E2-1-G", "GISS-E2-1-H",                                           "HadGEM3-GC31-LL", "INM-CM4-8", "INM-CM5-0",                                            "IPSL-CM6A-LR", "MIROC-ES2L", "MIROC6",                                            "MPI-ESM1-2-HR", "MPI-ESM1-2-LR", "MRI-ESM2-0",                                           "UKESM1-0-LL"))

title: The chooseGCM contribution for Species Distribution Modeling
text: demonstration, use Araucaria angustifolia, brazilian pine, study case. flagship species widely modeled know, key species Atlantic Rainforest biodiversity hotspot. Species records obtained GBIF cleaned excluding records outside native region NAs. set records used build shape accessible area merging buffers 500 km around record.  Using caretSDM package, transformed accessible area shape 20 km regular grid projected coordinate reference system (CRS) 6933, suitable metric CRS Brazil. CRS keeps area cell equal along study area, avoiding meridian convergence influence area results. added predictors data (WorldClim’s current data previously downloaded) grid averaging values falling cell. Finally, excluded “quarter” variables avoid statistical biases. avoid use multiple records environmental information, included species records grid, filtering one record per cell. using caretSDM, inform CRS coordinates transforms internally records grid’s CRS. Data cleaning routine excluded records NAs, coordinates capitals, countries’ centroids, duplicated coordinates, identical latitude/longitude, invalid coordinates, non-terrestrial coordinates, records falling within grid cell. Coordinates scientific institutions kept since multiple important institutions species native region accessible area. final number records species 364.
code: occ_data <- geodata::sp_occurrence("Araucaria", "angustifolia") occ_data <- occ_data |>   dplyr::filter(lon >= -64) |>    dplyr::filter(lon <= -33) |>    dplyr::filter(lat <= -19.5) |>    dplyr::filter(lat >= -33)  study_area_Araucaria <- na.omit(occ_data[,c("lon", "lat")]) |>   sf::st_as_sf(coords= c(1,2), crs = 4326) |>    sf::st_buffer(dist = 500000) |>    sf::st_union() plot(study_area_Araucaria, axes=T) tictoc::tic("Building sdm_area object") sa <- caretSDM::sdm_area(sf::st_as_sf(study_area_Araucaria),                              cell_size = 20000,                              crs = 6933,                              gdal = T) |>    caretSDM::add_predictors(stars::read_stars(list.files("~/storage/WC_data/current/climate/wc2.1_10m/",                                                full.names = T),                                     along = "band",                                     normalize_path = F)) |>    caretSDM::set_predictor_names(c("bio1",  "bio2",  "bio3",  "bio4",  "bio5",                                    "bio6",  "bio7",  "bio8",  "bio9",  "bio10",                                    "bio11", "bio12", "bio13", "bio14", "bio15",                                   "bio16", "bio17", "bio18", "bio19"))  |>   caretSDM::select_predictors(c("bio1", "bio2",  "bio3",  "bio4",  "bio5", "bio6",                                  "bio7", "bio12", "bio13", "bio14", "bio15")) ## ! title: The chooseGCM contribution for Species Distribution Modeling
text: Variable selection performed WorldClim 2.1 bioclimatic variables previously excluding ‘quarter’ variables avoid statistical biases (Booth, 2022). also performed variance inflation factor (VIF) selection routine variable higher VIF variable pair highest Pearson correlation excluded correlations lower 0.5. Variables remaining bio3 (isothermality), bio4 (temperature seasonality), bio5 (max temperature warmest month), bio12 (annual precipitation) bio15 (precipitation seasonality).
code: # Variable selection routine tictoc::tic("Variable selection") i <- caretSDM::vif_predictors(i, th = 0.5) i ##             caretSDM            ## ............................... ## Class                         : input_sdm ## --------  Occurrences  -------- ## Species Names                 : Araucaria angustifolia  ## Number of presences           : 364  ## Data Cleaning                 : NAs, Capitals, Centroids, Geographically Duplicated, Identical Lat/Long, Invalid, Non-terrestrial, Duplicated Cell (grid)  ## --------  Predictors  --------- ## Number of Predictors          : 11  ## Predictors Names              : bio1, bio2, bio3, bio4, bio5, bio6, bio7, bio12, bio13, bio14, bio15  ## Area (VIF)                    : all ## Threshold                     : 0.5 ## Selected Variables (VIF)      : bio3, bio4, bio5, bio12, bio15 tictoc::toc() ## Variable selection: 0.206 sec elapsed

text: aim modeling highlight effect GCMs GCMs selection, used one machine learning algorithm build models: naive bayes, simple quick algorithm. proper modeling hypothesis test probably use algorithms covering variety modeling approaches. searched optimal hyperparameters using grid-based approach 10 different combinations. validate models, used cross-validation approach 4-folds. fold, area receiver operating characteristic curve calculated (AUC).

text: selected four sets GCMs chooseGCM: (1) baseline, global set including GCMs; (2) smallest subset GCMs selected using hierarchical clustering mean distance closer global mean distance; (3) smallest subset GCMs selected using K-means clustering algorithm mean distance closer global mean distance; (4) subset GCMs automatically provided Closestdist algorithm. pre-analysis, subsets generated hierarchical K-means clustering returned subset size three. sense, also considered important analize two sets: (5) random set, includes three randomly selected GCMs; (6) subset GCMs selected using Closestdist algorithm size equals three.

title: Selecting General Circulation Models for Species Distribution Modeling
text: liked chooseGCM, get know packages. Currently, also caretSDM package, package run Species Distribution Modeling, also used article Esser, L.F., Bailly, D., Lima, M.R., Ré, R. 2025. chooseGCM: Toolkit Select General Circulation Models R. Global Change Biology , 31(1), e70008. Available : https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.70008. test chooseGCM using SDMs. Three breakthroughs distinguish caretSDM: strong geoprocessing background allows automation spatial data handling rescaling data common grid, possibility model distributions using river networks (via segmented lines), overcoming limitations aquatic species, also enabling interactive data viewing without use external GIS software; underlying ML tools allows integration 115+ classification algorithms automated workflows, hyperparameter tuning ensemble prediction, eliminating coding barriers advanced techniques, allowing flexibility experienced users; use recyclable objects, designed track analysis steps within single class, enhancing transparency scientific rigor. caretSDM available GitHub CRAN:
code: install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("luizesser/caretSDM") install.packages("caretSDM")

title: Distance between General Circulation Models (GCMs) — closestdist_gcms
text: s list stacks General Circulation Models (GCMs). var_names Character. vector names bioclimatic variables compare, '' include available variables. study_area Extent object, object Extent object can extracted. what: Optimize the number of clusters for a dataset — optk_gcms
title: Optimize the number of clusters for a dataset — optk_gcms
text: function performs clustering analysis dataset determines optimal number clusters based specified method.

title: Optimize the number of clusters for a dataset — optk_gcms
code: optk_gcms(   s,   var_names = c("bio_1", "bio_12"),   study_area = NULL,   cluster = "kmeans",   method = "wss",   n = NULL,   nstart = 10,   K.max = 10,   B = 100 )

title: Optimize the number of clusters for a dataset — optk_gcms
text: s list stacks General Circulation Models. var_names Character. vector names variables compare ''. study_area Extent object, object Extent object can extracted. object defines study area cropping masking rasters. cluster character string specifying method build clusters. Options 'kmeans' (default) 'hclust'. method character string specifying method use determining optimal number clusters. Options 'wss' within-cluster sum squares, 'silhouette' average silhouette width, 'gap_stat' gap statistic method. Default 'wss'. n integer specifying number randomly selected samples use clustering analysis. NULL (default), data used. nstart Numeric. number random sets chosen. Default 10. Argument passed `stats::kmeans()`. K.max Numeric. maximum number clusters consider. Default 10. Argument passed `factoextra::fviz_nbclust()`. B Integer. number Monte Carlo (“bootstrap”) samples. Default 100. Argument passed `cluster::clusGap()`.

title: Download WorldClim v2.1 Bioclimatic Data — worldclim_data
text: period Character. Can 'current' 'future'. variable Character. Specifies variables retrieve. Possible entries : 'tmax', 'tmin', 'prec', /'bioc'. year Character vector. Specifies year(s) retrieve data . Possible entries : '2030', '2050', '2070', /'2090'. gcm Character vector. Specifies GCM(s) consider future scenarios. See table available options. ssp Character vector. SSP(s) future data. Possible entries : '126', '245', '370', /'585'. resolution Numeric. Specifies resolution. Possible values 10, 5, 2.5, 30 arcseconds. path Character. Directory path save downloaded files. Default NULL.

title: Download WorldClim v2.1 Bioclimatic Data — worldclim_data
text: function return value.

title: Download WorldClim v2.1 Bioclimatic Data — worldclim_data
text: function creates folder path. downloaded data stored folder. Note: possible retrieve large volume data, recommended due large file sizes. example, datasets 30 arcseconds resolution can exceed 4 GB. function fails retrieve large datasets, consider increasing timeout setting options(timeout = 600). increase timeout 10 minutes.
